subject: Re: on vs. ah
msgSnippet: I m not talking about ah vs. awe, I m talking about A-h vs O-x (32/34).  I just want to know what the difference is and where to find it.  Considering as the
messageBody:
I'm not talking about ah vs. awe, I'm talking about A-h vs O-x
(32/34). I just want to know what the difference is and where to
find it. Considering as the sounds are so close, I wouldn't be able
to hear any accent regardless of which one is used (or ARE they
close?).


--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Chuck Peck <chuck091956@y...>
wrote:
> Since it's a Phonic script, why any rules. If you like
> to say something with a Ah sound, say it, if you like
> Awe sounds use it.
>
> What I've found to be a benefit of QS is that I can
> hear the writer acent within the writing and I like
> that.
>
> Chuck
>
> --- kyudosha <kyudosha@y...> wrote:
> > My main problem, however, is that there seems to be
> > no
> > easily-definable rule as to which character to use
> > under which
> > circumstances. Shouldn't there be a convention as
> > to which is used or
> > not used if no differences are perceived? Should it
> > be 32 or 34 for
> > QS?
> >
> > Perhaps if a British person could explain to me, in
> > fairly
> > straightforward terms, how they know which sound
> > goes where when they
> > see it written, it will click for me. Or is it
> > simply a matter of
> > memorization?
> >
> > Are there any American English speakers who hear
> > these differences and
> > can illuminate me?
> >
>
>
> __________________________________

I'm not talking about ah vs. awe, I'm talking about A-h vs O-x 
(32/34).  I just want to know what the difference is and where to 
find it.  Considering as the sounds are so close, I wouldn't be able 
to hear any accent regardless of which one is used (or ARE they 
close?).
